alert: As the pH goes, so goes my patient.
q: According to Klimek, what happens when pH goes UP (Alkalosis)?
rationale: Alkalosis makes the body irritable: high HR, high reflexes, seizures. (Except Potassium goes DOWN).

q: What are the signs of Acidosis?
rationale: Acidosis depresses the CNS: lethargy, low HR, respiratory arrest. (Potassium goes UP).

q: Which acid-base imbalance causes Kussmaul respirations?
rationale: Remember MAC Kussmaul (Metabolic Acidosis causes Kussmaul to blow off CO2).

q: What causes a High Pressure ventilator alarm?
rationale: High pressure means the machine has to push harder against resistance (kinked tube, secretions).

q: What are the toxic effects of Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin)?
rationale: Think mice (mycin) have big ears (Oto) and kidneys are shaped like ears (Nephro).

alert: Trough: 30 min before dose. Peak: Depends on route.
q: When is a trough level drawn?
rationale: Trough is the lowest concentration, always drawn immediately before the next dose is given.

fact: Uppers: Caffeine, Cocaine, PCP/LSD, Meth, Adderall.
q: What are the symptoms of an "Upper" overdose?
rationale: Uppers stimulate the CNS; everything goes UP.

q: What is the priority for a "Downer" overdose?
rationale: Downers depress the CNS; too much can stop breathing.

alert: Upper Withdrawal = Down. Downer Withdrawal = Up.
q: What happens during withdrawal from a Downer?
rationale: The body was suppressed; remove the suppressant and the body rebounds upward (seizures, tachycardia).

alert: Max 40 mEq/L. High K+ stops heart.
q: How should Potassium never be administered?
rationale: IV Push potassium causes instant cardiac arrest. Always dilute in a bag.

q: What is the effect of Calcium Channel Blockers?
rationale: They are negative inotropes, chronotropes, and dromotropes (weaken, slow, and block conduction).

alert: Lower HR/BP. Do not give to Asthmatics.
q: Why are Beta Blockers contraindicated in Asthma?
rationale: Non-selective beta blockers block beta-2 receptors in the lungs, causing constriction.

q: Which lab monitors Coumadin (Warfarin)?
rationale: PT/INR is for Coumadin. PTT is for Heparin.

alert: S/E: Fatigue, Muscle weakness. Don't drink alcohol.
q: What patient teaching is needed for Baclofen (Lioresal)?
rationale: It relaxes muscles and sedates the CNS; combining with alcohol enhances sedation.

q: What drug treats Malignant Hyperthermia?
rationale: Dantrolene acts directly on skeletal muscle to stop the rigidity and heat production.

q: How does Kayexalate work?
a: Exchanges Sodium for Potassium in the gut
rationale: It acts as a resin in the bowel, trading sodium ions for potassium ions, which are pooped out.

q: Which insulin can be given IV drip?
rationale: Regular insulin is the only one safe for IV administration.

q: When do you draw a peak level for an IV drug?
rationale: This captures the highest concentration in the blood.

q: When are Standard Precautions used?
rationale: Standard precautions apply to contact with blood, body fluids, non-intact skin, and mucous membranes for all patients.

q: Which diseases require Contact Precautions?
a: MRSA, RSV, Staph, Wound infections, Enteric (C-diff)
rationale: Contact is for anything transmitted by touching skin or surfaces (MRS. WEE mnemonic).

q: Which diseases require Droplet Precautions?
a: Sepsis, Scarlet Fever, Strep, Pertussis, Pneumonia, Flu, Meningitis
rationale: Droplets travel 3 feet; a mask is required. (SPIDERMAN mnemonic).

q: Which diseases require Airborne Precautions?
rationale: Tiny particles float in the air. MTV mnemonic: Measles, TB, Varicella.

q: What is the correct order for putting on PPE?
rationale: Start big (Gown), move up to face (Mask/Goggles), end with hands (Gloves).

q: What is the correct order for removing PPE?
rationale: Remove dirtiest first (Gloves), protect face/airway last (Mask).

alert: New order q24h. MD check within 1h.
q: How often must a restraint order be renewed for an adult?
rationale: Restraints are highly regulated; orders expire daily.

q: What is the COAL mnemonic for canes?
rationale: You hold the cane on the strong side to support the weak side.

fact: Even for Even, Odd for Odd.
q: Use an even-numbered gait (2 or 4) when weakness is...?
rationale: If both legs are weak (bilateral), use 2-point or 4-point. If one leg is broken (unilateral/odd), use 3-point.

q: Who is the priority patient?
rationale: The patient with a new, changing, or unstable condition always comes first.

alert: Brain > Lungs > Heart > Liver > Kidney > Pancreas.
q: In a tie for priority, use the modifying phrase to find the...?
rationale: If two patients are unstable, prioritize the one with the more vital organ failure (Brain/Lung vs Kidney).

alert: No IVs, No Teaching, No Assessment (Admission).
q: Can an LPN perform an admission assessment?
rationale: Admission/Discharge assessments require advanced judgment and planning; RN only.

q: Can a UAP take vitals on a stable patient?
rationale: Routine vitals on stable patients are within the UAP scope.

q: What is the difference between Laminectomy and Laminotomy?
rationale: Ectomy removes the whole lamina; Otomy removes a small part to make space.
